search_results.title: The fate of France's prime minister is in the far right's hands
search_results.text:
Subscribers only

Prime Minister François Bayrou, in the Alpine town of Briançon, on June 27, 2025. JEFF PACHOUD / AFP

You have to take victories where you can. Prime Minister François Bayrou, when speaking to visitors to his office, has marked each stage of his time in office in a rather unusual way. "I've surpassed \[Michel\] Barnier!" he declared to one visitor in March, after having outlasted his predecessor, whose [government was toppled](https://www.lemonde.fr/en/france/article/2024/12/04/french-government-toppled-in-historic-no-confidence-vote_6735189_7.html) after three months and eight days. "For three days now, I've surpassed \[Bernard\] Cazeneuve," Bayrou boasted to another in May, referring to [the Socialist](https://www.lemonde.fr/en/france/article/2024/08/30/former-socialist-figure-emerges-as-serious-contender-for-french-pm_6723879_7.html) who held the office for the last five months and nine days of François Hollande's presidency, in 2016-17. search_results.title: French President Emmanuel Macron Appoints New Cabinet After Previous Government’s Collapse
search_results.text:
Advertisement

[SKIP ADVERTISEMENT](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/12/23/world/europe/macron-new-cabinet-france.html#after-top)

You have a preview view of this article while we are checking your access. When we have confirmed access, the full article content will load.

President Emmanuel Macron of France on Monday appointed a new cabinet less than three weeks after the previous government collapsed over a bitter budgetary stalemate.

It was unclear how long the government might last or whether it would be able to assuage broader concerns about political instability in Europe at a time when the region faces significant security and economic challenges.

The center-right orientation of the new French government roughly mirrors that of the previous one, which lasted less than three months after coming under attack from the left and the far right in Parliament. It demonstrates that Mr. Macron and his new prime minister, François Bayrou, remain committed to the idea that France can be gover

search_results.title: The new ministers in the French government
search_results.text:
Emmanuel Macron will bring François Bayrou's government together at the Élysée Palace on 3 January for the first meeting of the Council of Ministers.  Photo: Shutterstock

More than a week after his appointment as Prime Minister, François Bayrou has unveiled the new government.

On Monday evening, French Prime Minister François Bayrou named the new ministers who will make up his government. New ministers, you say? Not really, the change is not now.

They will remain in their posts: Bruno Retailleau, minister of the interior, Jean-Noël Barrot, minister of Europe and foreign affairs, Sébastien Lecornu, minister of the armed forces, Rachida Dati, minister of culture, Annie Genevard, minister of agriculture and food sovereignty, Catherine Vautrin, minister of labour, health, solidarity and families and Agnès Pannier-Runacher, minister of ecological transition, biodiversity, forestry, the sea and fisheries.

Among those joining (or should we say returning to) the government are two former p

# Macro

metadata.title: Which grouping will the Prime Minister of France belong to on December 31, 2025?
metadata.description:
In 2024, France underwent a [political crisis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024%E2%80%932025_French_political_crisis) when President Emmanuel Macron called for snap elections. The [New Popular Front](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Popular_Front) (NFP) won the most seats in parliament (180), while Macron's centrist coalition, [Ensemble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ensemble_\(political_coalition\)), won 159. [Cooperation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_French_legislative_election#After_the_first_round) betweeen these two coalitions meant that [National Rally](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Rally)'s coalition ended up with only 142 seats, despite getting the most votes in the election.

Since no coalition reached the 289 seats needed for a majority, the elections resulted in a hung parliament. Macron refused to apppoint a prime minister from NFP, with the caretaker government remaining in place for 51 days. [Michel Barnier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michel_Barnier "Michel Barier"), a member of [The Republicans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Republicans_\(France\)) (Republican Right) was then appointed Prime Minister. Barnier's government lasted for 3 months, until it was brought down by a vote of no confidence, the shortest tenure of any Prime Minister during the Fifth Republic.

Barnier was then succeeded by [François Bayrou](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Bayrou), the leader of [Modem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Movement_\(France\)) (The Democrats) who remains the PM as of September 1, 2025, however, in late August, Bayrou announced a motion of confidence to be held on September 8, in order to seek parliamentary backing for his plan to cut public spending. National Rally, the [Socialist Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socialist_Party_\(France\) "Socialist Party (France)"), the Greens and [La France Insoumise](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_France_Insoumise "La France Insoumise") announced that they would vote against, which would effectively bring down the current government.

`{"format":"metac_reveal_and_close_in_period","info":{"post_id":39700,"question_id":39077}}`
metadata.resolution_criteria:
This question will resolve as the National Assembly grouping who the Prime Minister of France belongs to at 12:00 CET December 31, 2025.

If the Prime Minister does not belong to any of the listed options, this question will resolve as **Other**.

If there is no Prime Minister or if the Prime Minister is part of a caretaker government, this question will resolve as **No Prime Minister**.
metadata.fine_print:
The [official site of the government](https://www.info.gouv.fr/composition-du-gouvernement) will be the primary source of who is the Prime Minister, and the Interior Ministry will be the source as to which grouping they belong to.

If a National Assembly grouping changes name, this question will resolve as the former name.
